questions.question_text_1: A 6000 rpm magnetic disk is being used to store data. The disk can only spin in one direction and is operating at 6000 revolutions per minute. If the operating system sends a request to the disk controller to fetch data from the disk, but by the time the request reached the disk controller, the information had already moved 35 degrees passed the reader, what will be the latency (in milliseconds) before it can start retrieving data?
question_texts: A 6000 rpm magnetic disk is being used to store data. The disk can only spin in one direction and is operating at 6000 revolutions per minute. If the operating system sends a request to the disk controller to fetch data from the disk, but by the time the request reached the disk controller, the information had already moved 35 degrees passed the reader, what will be the latency (in milliseconds) before it can start retrieving data?

questions.question_text_1: Consider the following sorting algorithm which sorts any given unsorted array of numbers in ascending order. What would be its time complexity? (Assume appending and deleting an element from an array does not affect time complexity)  Step 1: Create an empty array. Step 2: Find the element in the unsorted array with the minimum value. Step 3: Append this element to the array created in step 1. Step 4: Delete this element from the unsorted array. Step 5: Repeat steps 1 to 4 until the unsorted array is empty.
question_texts: Consider the following sorting algorithm which sorts any given unsorted array of numbers in ascending order. What would be its time complexity? (Assume appending and deleting an element from an array does not affect time complexity)  Step 1: Create an empty array. Step 2: Find the element in the unsorted array with the minimum value. Step 3: Append this element to the array created in step 1. Step 4: Delete this element from the unsorted array. Step 5: Repeat steps 1 to 4 until the unsorted array is empty.

props.summary:
Here’s a structured summary of the **core topics, concepts, principles, and equations** essential for the **"Modern Application Development 1"** exam, along with **Mermaid knowledge graphs** to visualize relationships. --- --- ### **1. Core Topics & Concepts** #### **A. Web Development (HTML, CSS, Flask, REST APIs)** 1. **HTML Forms & HTTP Methods** - `GET` vs. `POST`: - `GET`: Data appended to URL (query string). Used for non-sensitive data (e.g., search queries). - `POST`: Data sent in the request body. Used for sensitive data (e.g., passwords). - Example: ```html
``` - Submitting `"Mahesh"` sends: `GET /submit?username=Mahesh`. 2. **CSS Specificity & Inheritance** - Order of precedence: `!important` > Inline styles > IDs > Classes > Tags. - Example: ```css .two { color: red !important; } /* Highest priority */

Text

/* Renders as red */ ``` 3. **Flask & RESTful APIs** - **Flask-Restful**: - Define resources with HTTP methods (`GET`, `POST`, `PUT`, `DELETE`). - Example: ```python from flask_restful import Resource, Api class Todo(Resource): def get(self, todo_id): return {"todo_id": todo_id} api.add_resource(Todo, "/todo/") ``` - **Request Handling**: - `request.args`: Query parameters (e.g., `?key=value`). - `request.json`: Parsed JSON body (for `POST/PUT`). - `request.form`: Form data (for `POST` with `Content-Type: multipart/form-data`). 4. **Jinja2 Templating** - Syntax: - `{{ variable }}`: Output a variable. - `{% for item in list %}`: Loop. - `{% extends "base.html" %}`: Inheritance. - Example: ```jinja2
    {% for user in users %}
  • {{ user.name }}
    • {% endfor %}
``` 5. **SQLAlchemy & Database Models** - Define models with `db.Model`: ```python class User(db.Model): id = db.Column(db.Integer, primary_key=True) name = db.Column(db.String(50), unique=True) ``` - Relationships: - `db.ForeignKey`: One-to-many. - `db.relationship`: Many-to-many (with association tables). 6. **HTTP Status Codes** - `200 OK`: Success. - `201 Created`: Resource created. - `400 Bad Request`: Client error. - `404 Not Found`: Resource missing. - `500 Internal Server Error`: Server error. --- #### **B. Testing (Pytest, Coverage)** 1. **Pytest Basics** - Write test functions with `assert`. - Example: ```python def test_add(): assert add(2, 3) == 5 ``` - Run tests: ```bash pytest test_file.py -v ``` 2. **Test Selection & Markers** - `-k`: Select tests by name (e.g., `pytest -k "test_add"`). - `-m`: Select tests by marker (e.g., `@pytest.mark.slow`). - Example: ```python @pytest.mark.marker1 def test_case1(): assert square(5) == 25 ``` Run with: `pytest -m marker1`. 3. **Coverage Types** | Type | Description | Example Test Cases | |--------------------|----------------------------------------------|-----------------------------| | **Function** | Every function is called at least once. | `foo()` | | **Statement** | Every line of code is executed. | `foo(1, 1)` | | **Branch** | Every `if/else` branch is tested. | `foo(1, 1)` and `foo(1, 0)` | | **Condition** | Every sub-condition (e.g., `x > 0 && y > 0`) is tested. | `foo(0, 1)` and `foo(1, 0)` | --- #### **C. Version Control (Git)** 1. **Git Commands** - `git rm --cached `: Remove from staging but keep locally. - `git commit -m "message"`: Commit changes. - `git push`: Upload to remote. 2. **Branching & Merging** - `git branch`: List branches. - `git checkout -b new-branch`: Create and switch branches. --- #### **D. Cloud Computing (PaaS, IaaS)** 1. **Service Models** - **IaaS**: Infrastructure as a Service (e.g., AWS EC2). - **PaaS**: Platform as a Service (e.g., Heroku, Azure App Service). - **SaaS**: Software as a Service (e.g., Gmail). 2. **Storage Types** - **Hot Storage**: Low latency, high cost (e.g., S3). - **Cold Storage**: High latency, low cost (e.g., Amazon Glacier). --- #### **E. Algorithms & Complexity** 1. **Time Complexity** - **Selection Sort-like Algorithm** (Question 31): - Steps: 1. Find min element in unsorted array: `O(N)`. 2. Repeat `N` times: `O(N) * N = O(N²)`. - **Answer**: `O(N²)`. --- #### **F. Networking (IPv4, Bandwidth)** 1. **IPv4 to Hexadecimal** - Convert each octet to hex: - `192` → `C0`, `168` → `A8`, `72` → `48`, `101` → `65`. - **Answer**: `C0A8 4865`. 2. **Disk Latency Calculation** - **Formula**: ``` Latency (ms) = (Degrees Missed / 360) * (60,000 / RPM) ``` - Example (Question 3): - `35°` missed, `6000 RPM`: ``` Latency = (35 / 360) * (60,000 / 6000) = 0.097 * 10 ≈ 0.97 ms ``` - **Wait for full rotation**: `10 ms - 0.97 ms = 9.03 ms`. - **Answer**: `9.03 ms`. 3. **Bandwidth vs. Data Consumption** - **Data = Bandwidth × Time**. - Example (Question 25): - User 2: `10 Mbps × 8 hours = 80 Mb` (highest). --- #### **G. Software Testing Types** | Type | Description | Example | |---------------------|----------------------------------------------|-----------------------------| | **Regression** | Ensure new changes don’t break existing functionality. | Re-run all tests after a bug fix. | | **User Acceptance** | Validate software with real users. | Beta testing. | | **System** | Test the complete system. | End-to-end workflows. | | **Automation** | Scripted testing (e.g., Selenium). | Automate login tests. | --- ### **2. Key Equations** #### **A. Disk Latency** ``` Latency (ms) = (Degrees Missed / 360) × (60,000 / RPM) ``` #### **B. Data Consumption** ``` Data (Mb) = Bandwidth (Mbps) × Time (hours) × 3600 ``` --- ### **3. Mermaid Knowledge Graphs** #### **Graph 1: Web Development Concepts** ```mermaid graph TD A[Web Development] --> B[Frontend] A --> C[Backend] B --> D[HTML] B --> E[CSS] B --> F[JavaScript] C --> G[Flask] C --> H[REST APIs] C --> I[Database] I --> J[SQLAlchemy] I --> K[SQLite] G --> L[Jinja2 Templating] H --> M[HTTP Methods] M --> N[GET] M --> O[POST] M --> P[PUT] M --> Q[DELETE] ``` #### **Graph 2: Testing Concepts** ```mermaid graph TD A[Testing] --> B[Unit Testing] A --> C[Integration Testing] A --> D[System Testing] B --> E[Pytest] E --> F[Fixtures] E --> G[Markers] E --> H[Coverage] H --> I[Function Coverage] H --> J[Branch Coverage] H --> K[Condition Coverage] ``` #### **Graph 3: Git Workflow** ```mermaid graph LR A[Working Directory] -->|git add| B[Staging Area] B -->|git commit| C[Local Repository] C -->|git push| D[Remote Repository] D -->|git pull| C C -->|git checkout| A ``` #### **Graph 4: Cloud Service Models** ```mermaid graph TD A[Cloud Computing] --> B[IaaS] A --> C[PaaS] A --> D[SaaS] B --> E[AWS EC2] C --> F[Heroku] C --> G[Azure App Service] D --> H[Gmail] D --> I[Dropbox] ``` #### **Graph 5: HTTP Request Flow** ```mermaid sequenceDiagram participant Client participant Server Client->>Server: GET /api?val=soccer (Query Params) Server-->>Client: Response (JSON) Client->>Server: POST /api (JSON Body) Server-->>Client: Response (Updated Data) ``` --- ### **4. Exam Tips** 1. **Flask-Restful**: - Use `@marshal_with` for structured JSON responses. - `request.args` (query params) vs. `request.json` (body). 2. **Pytest**: - `-k` for keyword filtering, `-m` for markers. - `1 passed, 2 deselected` means only tests matching the marker ran. 3. **Git**: - `git rm --cached` removes from staging but keeps the file locally. 4. **CSS**: - `!important` overrides all other styles. 5. **IPv4 Hex Conversion**: - Break into octets and convert each to hex. 6. **Bandwidth Calculation**: - Multiply bandwidth by time to find data consumed. 7. **Cold Storage**: - High latency, low cost (e.g., Amazon Glacier).
